projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head:
A PROCLAMATION,
Anent Per≈øons Travelling to or from this Kingdom.

opener.signed: WILLIAM and MARY by the Grace of GOD, King and Queen of Great-Britain, France and Ireland, Defenders of the Faith,
opener.salute: To Our Lyon King at Arms, and his Brethren Heraulds, Macers of Our Privy Council, Pur≈øevants, Me≈ø≈øengers at Arms, Our Sheriffs in that part, conjunctly and ≈øeverally, ≈øpecially con≈øtitute, Greeting:

div.p: Fora≈ømuch, as ≈øeveral Per≈øons of late have gone from this Our Antient Kingdom of Scotland into the Kingdom of France, and others have come from France into this Kingdom, upon evil De≈øigns again≈øt the Government; Therefore We with Advice of the Lords of Our Privy Council, Do hereby Inhibite and Di≈øcharge all Per≈øons what≈øoever, who intend to go out of this Our Antient Kingdom (during this time of War,) to depart furth of the ≈øame, until fir≈øt they apply them≈øelves to, and receive a Pa≈øs from any one of the ≈øaids Lords of Our Privy Council for the time being, within Twenty Miles of the ≈øaids Per≈øons their re≈øidence, and in ca≈øe there be not a Privy Coun≈øellor within that ≈øpace, then any two of the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Supply within the Shire, where the Per≈øon or Per≈øons craveing the ≈øaids Pa≈ø≈øes Dwell and Re≈øide, who have Accepted and Qualified them≈øelves by Law to Act as Commi≈ø≈øioners. And further, We with Advice fore≈øaid, Do hereby Require and Command all Per≈øons what≈øoever, who ≈øhall come into this Kingdom, at their Entry into the ≈øame, to pre≈øent their Per≈øons, and ≈øhew their Pa≈ø≈øes, or give a rational account of them≈øelves, and their bu≈øine≈øs, and from whence they came, upon Oath in ca≈øe of Su≈øpition, to the next Coun≈øellor, Ju≈øtice of Peace, Magi≈øtrat, or Officer of Our Army; with Certification to ≈øuch Per≈øons as ≈øhall pre≈øume to go furth of this Kingdom without Pa≈ø≈øes, or to come into the ≈øame, without pre≈øenting their Per≈øons and Pa≈ø≈øes, or giving account of them≈øelves as ≈øaid is, their Per≈øons ≈øhall be ≈øought for, and if apprehended, ≈øhall be committed Pri≈øoners, as Per≈øons ju≈øtly ≈øu≈øpect to be coming or going upon evil De≈øigns again≈øt the Government. And ≈øicklike, We with Advice fore≈øaid, Do hereby Prohibite and Di≈øcharge all Skippers, and Ma≈øters of Ships or Ve≈ø≈øels, that they receive no Pa≈ø≈øengers (be≈øides their Crue, for whom they mu≈øt be An≈øwerable) aboard their Ships, or Tran≈øport them either abroad out of this Kingdom, or from abroad into this Kingdom, except ≈øuch as ≈øhall be provided with Pa≈ø≈øes in manner fore≈øaid. And We with Advice fore≈øaid, Do hereby Require and Command the Skippers or Ma≈øters of any Ships, who are to go furth of this Kingdom, before they ≈øet Sail, to give in a Lift upon Oath, of all the Per≈øons aboard of their Ships, or who are to go abroad with them containing their true names and De≈øignations, to the next Magi≈øtrat, or Ju≈øtice of Peace, in the place from whence they are to Sail: And Requires and Commands the Skippers, or Ma≈øters of any Ships who ≈øhall come into this Kingdom, before they ≈øuffer any of their Pa≈ø≈øengers to Land, or go out of their Ships, to give in Li≈øts in manner and to the Per≈øons above appointed: With Certification to the ≈øaids Ma≈øters or Skippers, if they fail»ùie to give in the fore≈øaid Li≈øts, their Ships and Ve≈ø≈øels ≈øhall be Arre≈øted, and their Per≈øons ≈øecured, until they be proceeded again≈øt as Di≈øobeyers of Our Authority and the Law, and Abbettors of Rebels and Su≈øpected Per≈øons: And We hereby Require and Appoint the Per≈øons fore≈øaids, to whom Pa≈ø≈øes are Appointed to be pre≈øented by Pa≈ø≈øengers who ≈øhall come into this Kingdom, with all convenient Diligence, to Tran≈ømit to the Clerks of Our Privy Council a particular Accompt of ≈øuch Pa≈ø≈øengers with their Pa≈ø≈øes, as ≈øhall be pre≈øented to them from time to time, with the fore≈øaids Li≈øts to be given in by the Skippers or Ma≈øters of Ships, as ≈øaid is, as they will be An≈øwerable. And to the effect Our Plea≈øure in the Premi≈ø≈øes may be known, Our Will is herefore, and We Charge you ≈øtraitly and Command, that incontinent the≈øe our Letters ≈øeen, ye pa≈øs to the Mercat-Cro≈øs of Edinburgh, and to the Mercat-Cro≈ø≈øes of the whole remanent Head-Burghs of the ≈øeveral Shires and Stewartries within this Kingdom, and there, in ou ‚Ä¢ Name and Authority, by open Procla-mation, make Intimation and Publication of the Premi≈ø≈øes, that none may pretend ignorance, as ye will an≈øwer to Us thereupon. The which to do We commit to you, conjunctly and ≈øeverally Our full Power, by the≈øe Pre≈øents, delivering them by you, duly execute and indor≈øed again to the bearer.
div.closer:
Given under Our Signet at Edinburgh, the Fourth day of May, And of Our Reign the third Year, 1691.
Per Actum Dominorum Sti. Concilij. DA. MONCREIF, Cls. Secreti Concilij.
GOD ≈øave King WILLIAM and Queen MARY.
